cons: you are always on your feet.

pros: A lot of the people are very nice and very well meaning. It's a wonderful cause and a great Hospice. The actual Hospice is very well run, and provides an amazing standard of care.
cons: Management in the broader retail team could work harder to make cross functional teams work, could do more to make ideas happen quickly. Be prepared for projects to take ages to happen - if they happen at all.

job_title: RN Charge Nurse in London, England
pros: Beautiful gardens, good rate of pay, patient rooms are exemplary.
cons: Bullying management, blinkered clinical governance, tendency to refer to NMC rather than look at internal processes. Senior management created atmosphere of intimidation. High staff churn
Regularly dealing with thiefs, unclean donations. Profiling customers for theft.

job_title: Assistant Shop Manager in Streatham Hill, England
pros: a lot of responsabilities, tthey hire every type of people, very little discrimination
flexible volunteer hours, access to clothes
cons: not so much to do with covid, outdated system

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Clapham, London, England
pros:
Fantastic colleagues, competitive pay and benefits, wonderful position on Clapham Common with a beautiful 3.5 acres of landscaped gardens.
The care given to the patients is exceptional and employees are treated fairly and with respect. Trinity really encourages equality, diversity and inclusion and are the first ever hospice to be included in the National Centre for Diversity Top 100 employers Index. Organisations who make the Top 100, demonstrate excellent levels of employee retention and recruitment and clearly demonstrate how they value and respect the people that work for them.
cons: The characterful building sometimes gets a bit warm in the high summer months.

job_title: CNS in Clapham, South East England, England
pros: Escaping the office to clear your head
cons: Horrible place to work. Lot of dead wood that have worked there for too long. Uncomfortable atmosphere and a bullying culture which in my opinion is learned behaviour. Community managers are not supportive and the so called team leader is a nasty piece of work. Lots of favouritism goes on. Opinions don't matter you are told what to do. Peoples mental health have suffered working in this negative environment. Its reputation is well known. I couldn't wait to leave after my 3 years of hell.

review_title: PLEASE READ BEFORE APPLYING TO WORK IN THE RTH SHOPS!
pros:
I will say that the volunteers are amazing i have met some wonderful people! I was given gifts from them as they were sad i was leaving which was really sweet. On a whole there were nice people that you could have a chat with and be at ease around them while working.

The hospice is an amazing and positive place and working in the shops helping raising money for this cause is a great thing.
cons:
I do believe it does depend on the store manager you get.

in my personal experience my manager did not really communicate, give feedback or  support. I spent the first 4 weeks 5 days over 7 front of house serving customers and that is it. I did not feel that I was an assistant manager at all but a shop floor assistant!

A lot of the time when I display things, the next day I would come in and it would have been moved. I would price something, the next time I would come in and it would have been changed. Sometimes by only 1 or 2 pounds, and once by 50p! 

They are under staffed, you are always covering other store, sometimes at the last minute. 

You are expected to know everything even when you have not been told or shown or even when you have been shown once 4 or 5 weeks ago but are expected to remember!

When i started there was no hot water in my store and a broken toilet seat. this was the case way before i joined, the toilet seat only just got fixed when i left nearly 4 months later and still no hot water. The manager was always chasing it up with no luck, this shows how little they regard staff/volunteers. 

You rarely work with your manager.

No praise or positive comments even if to say that you are improving so for me personally it was draining and deflating as it was non stop stress. 

You get weekly visits and daily calls from higher management  just saying have you done this are you doing that constantly. It could be such a great job were you can work had and have fun but not with management that does not boost morale! 

they want you to put 50+ items out a day and keep a log of how many items you have been putting out, plus write an a4  page full of everything you did, what you sold for the next person coming in. You serve, keep the shop tidy, sort donations, steam clothes, gift aid, price, put out, take in donations, print tickets, etc and half the time you are on your own. which is fine that is the job but even after all that you are told it's not enough you have to do more.

cons: No room to advance due to size
